The youth, innocence, and inexperience of the minister never was better illustrated than it has been to-night. But youth, innocence and inexperience are not the most desirable things In a minister of a business government. He says that the cost of wages had increased and he has got down so low in parish politics that he has to resort to a miserable plea of this kind to account for his extravagance.' But if he had come to the county of Charlotte and had given me the opportunity, I would have found him more Grits there than were necessary to take all the census in New Brunswick, and at the same rates as were charged
ten years ago, and they would have been better men than those he appointed. And I have no doubt that the same thing can be said about the other counties in this country.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Will the minister kindly inform us the rates he is paying now per day to the enumerators or the staff of tabulators here ?
We pay different rates according to the work. The ordinary rate is $1.50 per dny, with an increase when the work is more important, or where a man has charge of a staff under him.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: What was paid in 1891 for the staff here ?
The same rates. The commissioners were paid $4 per family in 1901. and this year they are paid 1 cent per individual or name taken.
What was the chief commissioner in on cl* riding paid ?

They were paid on the schedule rates, equal to $4 per day for so many days accrued service In 1891 they were paid $4 per family, and expenses. This 'year they were paid a cent per name and an allowance foi expenses. In some counties they were paid $100, and in some few places more than that.
What was paid in East Simcoe in 1891 and 1901 to the commissioner ?
In East Simcoe the total cost Jn 1S91 was $2,304.48, and this year $4,465.79.

East Simcoe offers a fail-example of the extravagance of this government in the taking of the census. The cost in 1901 was only $2,304 and in 1901 it had swelled to $4,4(35, and there was but a small increase in the population, and that principally in one or two towns. The reason why the expenses were swelled was because of 'the political leverage which had to be exercised in that riding. In 1891 there^ was only one commissioner, but political exigencies compelled the minister to appoint two in 3901, which swelled the expenses very considerably. In the town of Midland in 1891, one man enumerated the whole town, but in 1901, owing to public exigencies, the work was distributed among three, and these three, who were business men, took odd hours' of the day to do the work. All over the riding the same sort of thing was done.

I took the plan of appointing an enumerator for each polling subdivision, and roughly speaking there were about twice as many in 1891 as in 1901. The object was to have the census taken more quickly and much more information was required. There were 65 enumerators in East Simcoe last year.
And in 1891, how many?
Twenty-seven.

There is a case in point. The population was practically the same and the territory exactly the same. Yet we have 27 enumerators in 1891, aud 65 in 1901. I do not know what time the enumerators took up, because they claimed very little of my attention. But, speaking of my own town of Midland, who were these enumerators ? One was the express agent, who, when he had nothing to do, went about the census enumeration. And there was a clerk in a grocery store who occupied himself in odd moments in the same way
What were the names ?

White, Moore and Grice. But the names are immaterial. I am pretty confident that in 1891 one man did the work, and I will be bound to say that he was much better fitted to do it than all these three Put together. Yet, for this census three had to be appointed. The hon. minister has given some sort of a solution-that he had an enumerator appointed for each polling subdivision. As a matter of fact, there are the three polling subdivisions, so that worked out fairly.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: How many polling subdivisions are there in the riding ?

Sixty-five, I should judge. But, first as to the commissioners, the minister must have had representations that party exigencies required the appointment of two. Two were appointed. One was the magistrate, a lawyer by profession, and the other was the township clerk. These gentlemen must have been running into each others territory all the time. In how many other ridings of the province were there two commissioners ?

There were two chief commissioners in a number of ridings. I would have to go through the list to learn how many there were in Ontario. But where the circumstances were peculiar it was sometimes deemed advisable to appoint two commissioners, especially was that the case where there was a considerable proportion of people representing the two different languages that are current in this country. If there was a large area, that was another reason. Speaking from memory, I think that in the hon. gentleman's constituency the appointment of two was due to the fact that there Mr. BENNETT.
is a considerable French population in that riding.

Well, as to one of these reasons, neither of the commissioners appointed in East Simcoe could speak a word of French. And as to the plea of extended area, I may tell the minister that one of the commissioners unfortunately is a very bad cripple, a man who cannot walk about, but has to be lifted. One can readily understand how he could get over a large area of country. I may explain the circumstances to the minister to refresh his memory. One of these appointees was recommended by the Liberal candidate for the local legislature, and the other by the defeated candidate for the Commons. Both had to be appointed, and the country has to pay for them. If that is a fair sample of the way the census was conducted all over the country, it is clear that the great expense lias been due to the fact that so much has had to be done out of consideration for political exigencies.
No.
I have given the facts concerning the two chief commissioners, and they are quite in accordance with what I have said.
Will the hon. minister please say how many commissioners there were for Central Wellington ?
One.
What was his name ?
Thomas Harcourt.	.
What was the expense of taking the census in South Simcoe in 1891 and 1901 ?
In 1891 the cost was $1,341.41, and in 1901 it was $2,794.56.
Can the hon. minister give the reason for that increase ? Is it due to increase in the population or to any special circumstance ?
I could not give reasons beyond the general reasons I have given. I have not the details for this particular county.

If the hon. minister will look up the census of 1891 and compare it with that of 1901, he will find that there has been rather a decrease of population if anything. There is no change of circumstances that would account for this greater expense. While I am speaking, I would like to ask the figures for North Simcoe, as the hon. member for that riding is not here.
The figures for North Simcoe are: 1891 $1,728.62, and 1901. $2,890.05.
What were the respective figures for West Bruce ?
Is there any particular reason for that ?
I have no details to show the particular reason in this county.

I can, perhaps, give the minister an explanation with regard to that riding. No doubt, the enumerators had the figures of the preceding census, and when they went around the riding they found that the population had dropped from 22,377 to 17.925, a decrease in that riding in the province of Ontario, where there is so much so-called prosperity, of 4,452. I suppose the enumerators became very zealous and worked over time, probably with the expectation that they would be paid by the day, to find where these 4,452 people had gone.
Tne hon. gentleman will see the fallacy of that when he recollects that the enumerators were paid by the names they got, and if they did not get the names they did hot get the money.
How then did they get more money than in the previous census?
Were there two commissioners or one in North Simcoe and East Grey ?
In East Grey there was one commissioner.
How many in North Simcoe ?

One.
M* LENNOX. What was his name ?
Archibald Currie. In East Grey it was R. D. Carruthers.
In East Simcoe what were the amounts paid to the commissioners, Storey and Tudhope ?
Mr. Tudhope was paid $264.09, and Mr. Storey $301.80.
What amounts were allowed them for livery hire, if any ?
Nothing was given to the commissioners for horse hire.
What is the population of East Simcoe ?
Would the minister say what was the respective cost of taking the census in East Grey in 1891 and 1901 ?
Would the minister kindly tell me the cost in Centre Wellington in the two years ?
In 1891 the cost was $1,591.99 ; in 1901 it was $2,681.79.
What was the cost in East Northumberland ?
What was the cost in South Victoria ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Will the hon. gentleman kindly tell us what the population of the whole province of Ontario was in 1891 and 1901 ?
The total in 1891 was 2,114,321 ; the total in 1901 was 2,182,942.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Now, will the hon. gentleman give us the cost for 1891 and 1901 ?
The total cost in 1891 was $147,142.29 ; in 1901 it was $281,401.18.
Was there any riding in the Dominion in which it cost less in 1901 than in the previous census ?
I do not think there is a riding in which it cost less. The schedule of rates which was paid and the work which was done in every case, I think, were more.

Will the minister explain what it was that induced him to change the schedule of rates ? Was it a matter of intuition on the part of the minister, or was it after making inquiry, and after having endeavoured to get the work done a t the old rates ?

We knew that we were asking the enumerators to do a good deal more work ; and we knew also from inquiries that we could not find men to do the work as easily as they were apparently found in 1891. We consequently fixed the rates at what we thought was a fair salary to enable the enumerators to earn $3 a day if they did a fair days' work.
Would you reckon their labour as skilled or unskilled ?
I should call it skilled labour.
Does the minister understand that skilled labour was paid at a higher rate in 1901 than in 1891, as a rule 1
I think such labour as this, clerical labour, was paid higher in 1901 than in 1891.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Where did the minister find any difficulty in getting men to do the work ?
I could not tell the hon. gentleman off hand where a man refused, but there were a good many instances of that kind, and many representations made of the difficulty of finding men to do the work.

I know a gentleman in my riding who came down here for two years waiting for a job. He was perfectly competent and tried to get work on the hon. gentleman's staff and could'nt get it. I cannot see for my part why taking the census in East Northumberland cost in 1901 more than double what it did in 1891. The same class of men was employed, only they were Liberals, and of course their services were skilled. Perhaps some of the Grit heelers that were along with the machine the hon. gentleman wanted to pay as he is now paying Mr. Preston for hugging the machine.

When were the enumerators paid for the county of Lisgar ?
^ The MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE. The accounts were paid as they came in. I could not give the hon. gentleman the exact time, or even about the time. They were not all paid at once. The accounts of each enumerator come in and are checked over here, and as they are checked, and accepted, and passed by the auditor, they are paid.
Have any been paid during the last month or six weeks ?

I do not remember whether there were any paid in the last month or not. The accounts were in dispute in many counties but I could not say whether there are any in Lisgar. I will look up the facts in the department.

The information I have is that in a number of cases, in fact in all of the cases of disputed accounts in the county of Lisgar, an amicable settlement was made about the time of the late election. I hope the hon. minister will give the information before the item passes, together with the names of the enumerators there whose accounts were paid.

I can give the hon. gentleman the names of the enumerators at once, as I have the information under my hand. The dates of their payment I will have to get in the department, and I will be glad to do it if the hon. gentleman wishes it. I may say that the report which he has heard as to' there being an amicable settlement in regard to these accounts in Lisgar, and that the en-Mr. LENNOX.
umerators were all paid, is entirely unfounded, and, I think, if the hon. gentleman discusses the question with some of these enumerators, he will find that their accounts were not paid to their satisfaction. I regret to say that there are a great many of these cases all over the country, and I regret to say also that in a few instances we have not jet made a settlement of the accounts.
The hon. minister does not know whether they have been settled in Lisgar to the satisfaction of the enumerators ?
I can get the dates if the hon. gentleman wants them.
I would like to have them.

I would like to call the hon. minister's attention to the fact that we have not received that defiuite information that we are entitled to in regard to the question of increased remuneration for labour. I do not think the hon. minister has given us any basis upon which to judge whether a fair increase in the remuneration of these officers was made or not. If the hon. minister will say that he found that the percentage of wages for skilled or clerical labour had, in his estimation, and according to his investigation, increased 5, 10 or 15 per cent, or whatever percentage the hon. minister found that the remuneration had increased, we will have some reasonable means of ascertaining whether a fair arrangement was made or not. I understand that in the years that are past hon. gentlemen opposite maintained that the great object for a legislator to aim at was to make Canada a cheap country to live in, and that cheap food and cheaply paid labour were the great objects of legislation and of government. According to what we find to-night from the hon. Minister of Agriculture, this lias been made a very very dear country to live in. I would like to ask the hon. minister if he found, before he made this regulation, that labour was worth from 10 to 15 per cent, or some definite percentage, more in 1901 than in 1891, so that we can ascertain whether, in the first place, the conclusion he arrived at was correct in regard to what we know to be current in the country, and in the second place, whether the increase which he made was in accordance with that test.
I would like to ask the hon. minister who the enumerators were in the towns of Orillia, Gravenhurst and Fenetanguishene ?
I have the list of enumerators, but I have not attached to it the places in which they made their enumerations.
If the hon. minister will allow me to see the list perhaps I can select them.
In tlie meantime, will the hon. minister answer, ns far as possible, the question I submitted to him ?

The hon. gentleman (Mr. Lennox) asks whether there was a definite ascertainment of particular facts in regard to the increase in the general wages of the country. 1 may say to the hon. gentleman at once, no. That is a very difficult thing to find out, as a matter of fact. I have examined all the statistical records I can find in the country. I find that until the Labour Bureau was established here there was nothing in Canada frpm which one could make a definite statement as to the price of labour, but now that the Labour Bureau has been established that will be remedied, and in future the cost of labour will be on record so as to be available for statistical purposes. In the past no such record has been available. However, I formed my judgment on what I believed to be the general consensus of opinion and of knowledge in the country that the remuneration of all classes of skilled and clerical labour was higher than it had been, and also upon the fact that while in 1891 there wore a large number of temporarily unemployed and idle people, in 1901 there were comparatively few people who were not busily engaged in one kind of work or another who were not prepared to leave their work for temporary employment, and who could not leave their employment with advantage unless they got a fair remuneration. A number of instances are on record where men who were offered these positions refused to accept them, because they could not take them at the pay which was offered.
Is it not a fact that the hon. gentleman had thousands of applications more than he had positions for ?
No, it is not a fact.
W ill the hon. gentleman say that there have not been more applications than there were positions ?
I do not think the hon. gentleman would be correct in saying that there were any more applications than there were positions.
In 1891 we had, in St. Thomas, four enumerators, and in 1901. we had fourteen, and there were forty ready to take the positions if they could get them.

We did not have fifty applications from all parts of the country for positions as enumerators. Recommendations were made to us and the people who made the recommendations, in many instances, had to search out men to do the work.

As I understand the hon. minister, he says that there are no means of ascertaining whether the increase in the
rate of pay was fair or justified, that he was anxious to ascertain it but that he could not do so. Then, I understand that there was no reason for increasing the rate, there being no means of definitely ascertaining that there should be an increase in the rate. Am I right in assuming then that the main reason for increasing the remuneration was by reason of the increased number of questions asked and answered ?
That was one of the chief reasons.
Was that the chief reason ?
I think I may say it was the chief reason.

May I ask the hon. minister if any steps were taken to get information as to what wages are being paid now ?
The MINISTER OF AGRICULTt RE. In the ordinary schedules there are questions which indicate the pay that the people who are remunerated are receiving. Part of the questions which are asked are in that direction, and these results will be tabulated.
Was there any like schedule in 1891, so that you can make a comparison ?
No.
Did the minister say that the government first fixed the rates to be paid to the enumerators, and then increased them afterwards ?
No.
On what authority does the minister state that some who were offered the positions refused them on account of the lowness of the rate of pay.
Other people took the positions afterwards.

The figures given me by the minister with regard to South Victoria have whetted my appetite for further information. In 1891 the cost of taking the census for South Victoria was ,$1,253, and in 1901 it was $2,663, more than double. That county lias a less population now than it had in 1891. I wish to know who was the chief census commissioner there, what was he paid, what is the population now as compared with 1891, and how many enumerators were employed in both periods ?

In South Victoria the commissioner was F. C. Taylor. He was paid $299.55 all told. The population in 1891 was 20,455 and in 1901 it was 19,953. There were 17 enumerators in 1891 and 39 enumerators in 1901.
Was there anything paid the enumerators for horse hire.
Ill 1001 they were allowed $1.50 per ordinary day, and in 1801 they were allowed nothing for horse hire.
I asked the minister if it was not a fact that hundreds of applications were made for the position of enumerators as well as commissioners, more than there were vacancies to fill.
The applications were not made to Ottawa. They were made to the representatives of the Liberal party in the county and not to me.
Therefore the minister could not answer the question ?

No.
Mr. INGltAM. Then why did lie give an answer that was misleading to the House ?
I had reports sent to me.
Can you say now, that there were not more than fifty commissioners in ail Canada who applied for positions that had been filled ?

There were not fifty applications for enumerators who came to me. I understood there were no doubt a large number of applications in the different counties, and it was reported to me that it was difficult io find men to do the work at the rate of pay.

The minister stated that one of the chief reasons why they increased the pay of the enumerators and commissioners was on account of the scarcity of men to fill the position. I can tell him that in East Elgin hi; had more applications for positions than there were vacancies. That was the same, I venture to say, in every constituency in Canada except in perhaps a few sparsely settled districts and probably not In them. There was no reason to increase the pay on that account.

One of the main reasons given by the minister for the enormous cost of the last census was the difficulty of obtaining competent men to act as enumerators. Will the minister tell us what means were taken to obtain applications from capable men to fill these positions ?

Our friends in the different counties were asked to make recommendations and those whom they recommended were asked to forward specimens of their handwriting, and so on, in the form of a letter to the department so as to indicate whether the persons recommended were properly qualified by their education to do that work.
I have had the advantage of seeing the list of enumerators in

East Simcoe. I shudder to think what must be the lists sent in by some of them in the line of orthography. I notice the name of one gentleman who, under the wonderful power conferred on the Ontario government of appointing every one who may be useful from a party view to be a justice of the peace, has been appointed to that office. He was one of the enumerators selected by the Minister of Agriculture. He is a gentleman who believes in signing his name to all papers as a justice of the peace and he always spells it ' Justis of Pace.'
Some lion. MEMBERS. Oh.

If the minister had many more enumerators like that he did not put them through a very rigid educational examination. On looking over this list of enumerators for East Simcoe, I see in it the same old gang of political heelers of the Liberal party. It would not be a question of fitness, for that certainly was not the question in the selection of enumerators there, because we find that they were the old time division court clerks, license inspectors, bailiffs, and men of that ilk. These were tne enumerators for the riding of East Simcoe. As to their fitness by reason. of educatioii, I can only tell the minister that if the men got correct returns in East Simcoe, then I am very much mistaken. What are the facts of this census ? Let us take the province of Ontario. We find that there has been an increase in the province of 53,(557. In the cities of Ottawa, Toronto, Hamilton, London and Brantford there has been an increase of 55,900 odd, so that in the bulk of the province of Ontario the population, instead of increasing, has gone backwards. ' Can any one believe that in ridings where 1,he population was tumbling from 22,000 to 17,900-and this has gone on throughout the province generally, though I am glad to say not in all the ridings-there would be such a scarcity of men to do the work that the minister had to increase the pay ? As I have pointed out, party exigencies drove him to appoint two commissioners in the riding of East Simcoe, which of course increased the cost accordingly. Then he had to increase the number of enumerators from 27 in 1891 to 65 in 1901. I will refresh the minister's memory as to one of the requirements that were to be exacted from these enumerators. I suppose the minister has not forgotten the famous circular : first, on your oath, do not give anything away ; and next, send to the county secretary the names of all the lads in your division who are approaching 21. I think that is the reason why a good many of these men in East Simcoe were chosen-that they would have an utter disregard of their oath of office, and would do what I know they were doing-going about the riding getting all this information preparatory to "the revision of the voters' lists last fall. I can only speak of that one riding, but I have no doubt that if the non.

gentlemen study the lists in tlieir own rulings, they will find the same thing there- that' these men were selected as enumerators because they would be useful from a party point of view, and that is the reason thev were not g'oing to do the work at the rate that had been in force in 1891, but demanded a higher rate. That is the reason the minister was moved-and I suspect that the greatest pull came from the province of Ontario-to increase the rate from 3 cents per head to 5 cents. The minister cannot make any reasonable man believe that in those parts of the province of Ontario from which people were fleeing as if from a pestilence, it was difficult to obtain men to do the work. In East Simcoe these little doles which were given out to those men were perfect Godsends to them. A number of them were men who were pursuing their ordinary avocations, and this was money simply thrown to them on the side. It will not do for the minister to try to convince the country that these men were paid these excessive rates to take the census, because there was no complaint that the enumerators were under paid in 1891. It was simply and solely because they were so hungry that they had to be paid an excessive amount, and it was thrown to them as a sop and nothing else. The statement that the cost of labour had increased so much in the province of Ontario will not apply in East Simcoe, because most of these enumerators have no ordinary avocation save being hangers-on to a political party ; and I am bound to sav that if other members go through the lists of their own ridings, they will have the same experience there as I have had in East Simcoe. It was the hungry cry of the party followers, driven on by the members behind him, which drove the minister to increase the rates in 1901 over what was paid in 1891.

I am sorry to think that there are so many hungry people in Ontario. We have no such class of people in Nova Scotia, and particularly in the island of Cape Breton, where the value of labour has increased 25 to 40 per cent, and in some instances 50 per cent.
On account of the iron bounties.

The best class of people have moved to the Sydneys. Speaking for my own county, I can say that the men who were appointed enumerators there were perfectly qualified in every respect, and their returns, if examined, will show that they were not appointed because they were hungry, but because they were qualified to do the work that was entrusted to them. I think that will be found to be the general experience in the whole island of Cape Breton. We have no hungry people, I am happy to say, in the island of Cape Breton at the present time, but the people are prosperous, and are getting from 25 to 50 per cent better wages than they did in 1891.

I can only say, in answer to the hon. gentleman who has just spoken, that if times are so good in the riding of Victoria, which he represents, it is a wonder that some 1,500 people less are there now than there were 10 years ago.
Hon. Mr. ROSiS (Victoria). They have moved to the county of Cape Breton.
To get the benefit of the bounties.

The hon. member for East Simcoe (Mr. Bennett) must remember that there are iron bounties paid in Ontario, and in the town of Midland ; and if these accrue to the benefit of workingmen in the province of Nova Scotia in increased wages, and do not in the province of Ontario, we ought to know the reason why.

I grant the Finance Minister that they do accrue to the benefit of the country ; but there is this marked distinction between hon. gentlemen on this side of the House and hon. gentlemen on that side, that we on this side, not only when in power, but also when in opposition, have been favourable to iron bounties, while the hon. Minister of Finance and his friends placed themselves on record by a resolution when in opposition that iron bounties were a bane to the country, and voted against the giving of them, but they were very different when they came into power.

Well, as Mr. Rudyard Kipling says, that is another story. We do not happen to be discussing just now whether iron bounties are wise or unwise. There is the fact, that iron bounties are paid in both Cape Breton and Ontario, and the idea that they are peculiar to Cape Breton is a mistake, that is all.

I do not think that iron bounties exactly account for the increased cost, nor does the reason given by the Minister of Agriculture. His principal reason is that wages have increased between 1891 and 1901. We have some means of making a comparison. I have before me the report of the Ontario Bureau of Industries for the two periods, and I find that the wages of farm labourers in 1891 were $25.81 a month, and in 1901, $20.14. or a difference of 33 cents a month. Surely that cannot account for it. I think the ministei will be obliged to look around and find some other reason. He will certainly not find people in Ontario, who have been in the habit of employing men, agree with him that the difference in wages can account for the increase. Take the riding of East Grey. I find that in 1891 it cost $1,324 to take the census, whereas in 1901 it cost $3 500. or more than twice as much, notwitstanding the fact-and I speak from experience because I have been hiring men all along-that the wages paid in 1891 were about the same as were paid in 1901. When

these gentlemen were appealing to the people. they said that if they got into office they would make the country a cheap one to live in, but according to the minister it is dearer, because he says that on account of the increased cost of living we have to pay more wages. They also said they were going to exercise stringent economy, and yet they paid double in 1901 for the same work that was done in 1891.

So far as my county is concerned, there has been an increase in that county of over 1,200 during the last ten years. The hon. member who has just spoken must remember that the question of the cost of living is one that must always be considered in connection with the wages paid. Suppose a man gets $2 per day this year where he got $1 per day ten years ago, will it be fair to say that because his living cost him 50 cents per day when he only got a dollar, and .$1 per day when he gets $2, that the cost of living has increased ? In the one case he is 50 cents a day better off than the other. Speaking for my own county, except in two districts,
I had not an application to appoint a man to take the census. I had to- enumerate good men myself and ask them to do the work, except in two districts. My county is divided into two municipalities. In the one, in order that the work might be well done, I asked the warden of one of the districts if he would not he the commissioner for that particular district and he consented, in the other I appointed one of the best men I could And, who never applied at all. It may be different elsewhere, but I do not believe there is a man who took the census m Nova Scotia-I know there was none in the county of Guysborough-who could not make more money at something else during the time he took to do that work. The remuneration after all was not so very great; and 1 did not think that even in Ontario taking the census would be found such a very lucrative job. It certainly was not considered so in the province of Nova Scotia, and nobody was scrambling for the positions. We had to look for the men to take them. The two commissioners appointed in m.V county could have made twice as much money at other work during the time they gave to the census.

In my countv I was asked to recommend enumerators and several refused to accept. I had only very few applications. I have in my mind one from a certain gentleman who had taken the census twice before, and who claimed he was about the only man competent to do it. But when I found that he began to spell census with an ' s,' I began to doubt his qualifications. It was true that we did not take farm hands in our county to do the work, but men who were skilled in that particular line, and in several cases the men I asked to do it would not accept at all. I had very few apppli-Mr. SPROULE.
cations for the job, and when 1 called on some men to perform the work, they said they could earn more money at something else. It was no wind-fall .to our people to get such a job, and I am sorry to hear it was such a Godsend to the people in Ontario. In my simplicity, I had the idea that Ontario was rather ahead of us in that respect, and that tlie people there were not so badly off that they looked upon a week or ten days' work on the census as such a Godsend to them.

The hon. gentleman must remember that they had an eighteen-years' hunger on. I would ask why it was deemed necessary in the county of Guysborough, which has only a population .of 18,000, to appoint two or three commissioners ?
The county has two distinct municipalities, and there is a shore front of over 200 miles, and it was a saving to the department to have a commissioner in each municipality.
What is the minister's version V
v lion, friend from Guysborough recommended the men and I took his recommendation.

While accepting the statement of the hon. member for Guysborough, it seems rather strange that, if there were no men looking for the position, two gentlemen should have been appointed as chief commissioners for the small number of 18,000 people. There must have been some anxiety for the best positions when two were appointed where one had previously done the work.

There was no such thing. Neither of the men made any application. Had only one commissioner been appointed, he would have had to travel around a shore frontage of some 200 miles, and in appointing two men, travelling expenses were saved, and the government effected an economy of $200.
How many commissioners were appointed for West Elgin ?
There were two in West Elgin.
So in West Elgin, 25 miles long, the same rule does not apply as in Guysborough. Will the minister tell us if the same explanation would apply to West Elgin ?

In the first place West Elgin, I believe, is about 40 miles long, and in the second place, it is composed of parts of two municipal counties. The riding is not all in one municipal county, and it was thought better to have one man attend to the part in one county, and another man attend to the other part.
What does the hon. gentleman mean by a municipal county ?

In Ontario there are certain counties for municipal purposes. By the Gerrymander Act the ridings are not always bounded by the same boundaries as the municipalities. The county of Elgin comprises portions of two different county municipalities.
What was the cost of taking the census in West Elgin in 1891 and 1901 ?
Please give the figures for East Elgin ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Kindly give us the figures for Guysborough.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
The county was of the same size, I presume, under tlie corrupt Conservative government that did the work, and did it just as well, for $1,231, as it has been done last year for $3,301. My hon. friend from Simcoe informed the minister a few moments ago that the population of Ontario during the ten years had increased by 53,000 souls, while the population of four cities that lie named had made up that total increase. Now where has the increase taken place ? In all the smaller towns, villages and rural municipalities there is not a man in Ontario to-day who is satisfied with the census. I have before me tlie census in our town, and I find that in 1891 it was 3,069, and by this census it is 3,526. Here is a certificate from the county clerk taken from the assessment roll that simply gives the heads of families and their children. It takes the same count that the enumerators are supposed to take, and the assessor was doing the work at the same time that the enumerators were. The town clerk says :
Gananoque, October 17, 1901. The assessment roll for the town of Ganano-que for the present year, 1901, shows the popu-lation'to be 3,718.
(Sgd.) SAMUEL McCALLUM,
Town Clerk.
The enumerators of the hon. gentleman give the population as 3,526, or 192 less than the population in our town taken in the same month by the town authorities. I would like to know how the hon. gentleman will account for the great discrepancy there. Besides the four cities the member for Simcoe named show an increased population more than the total increase for Ontario that the hon. gentleman shows by his census. He must know, as everybody in Ontario knows, that the census for Ontario is not correct, because the Ontario Bureau of Statistics show a much larger increase, and my hon. friend here proved by the Ontario
Bureau of Statistics, made up by the same gentleman who has been at the head of this census staff, that the wages paid in 1891 were within 23 cents a month as high as those paid in 1901. The minister himself says that the men doing this kind of work must understand clerical work, and lie is paying to-day just the same prices that were paid for doing the same clerical work as was done in 1891. $1.50 and $2 a day-that is wliat they were paid in 1891. Where is the increase ? In the city of Ottawa, where living ought to be dearer, if in any place, lie is giving his staff the same pay as was given in 1891. namely. SI.t>0 and $2 a day. The hon. gentleman has at the head of his staff the same gentleman .who took the census during the two last decades, lie had the same machinery, but he had to find jobs [DOT] for his friends. What are the facts to-day? The present census will cost, by the time it is completed, more than double what the last census did. to say nothing about that $6,000 a year rent he is paying for a building that will not hold the staff doing the work. Let anybody go down to that building and say if $6,000 a year rent is not an outrageous price to pay for it, besides spending $10,000 or $12,000 for fitting it up. That is how this economical government are running the affairs of the country, and it is so in every department. This is a plain kind of work that any man ought to be able : to do, at least for the same amount of money that it cost ten years ago. The fact 1 is that labour lias not increased, ns proved by statistics here, and by gentlemen who are employing men. I have some 60 men employed in my factory at Gananoque. doing the same kind of work that they did ten years ago, and they are drawing the same pay now that they did then, and it is the same in every other factory.
Have you not a larger number now ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
No, I have no more, we have just about the same number that we had ten years ago, but we have another factory. The pay is the same. Every employer of labour knows that there is no such increase in wages. The hon. gentleman admits that he is paying his staff in the city of Ottawa just what the late government paid ten years ago, namely, $1.50 and $2 a day. But how did he obtain his staff ?
I am informed that each supporter behind him and each defeated candidate have a right to name one clerk to come down here on the census staff-213 clerks sent down from 213 constituencies in the Dominion of Canada, to fill this building renting at $6,000 a year, and they are crammed in there, tumbling over one another. But there had to be one taken on from each constituency, and I presume that if each supporter and each defeated candidate had the privilege of naming five clerks there would have been five from each constituency taken on, because I understood that more came than the

hon. gentleman could find room for. The minister will find that the estimate he made the other day that it would cost $170,000 more to complete the census, will be exceeded, and that it will take a quarter of a million dollars more to complete a work that was done in 1891 for $549,000. The city of Kingston had a census taken, and they eiaim a large shrinkage. Owen Sound, Toronto, and almost every other place has had a similar experience. In many cases they were so disappointed that they had the census taken over again, and the Minister of Agriculture has heard from them. Ontario does not show anything like the population which is given by the Bureau of Statistics.
Mr. OLIVER, The case I have to lay before the minister is the direct opposite of that of these hon. gentlemen. They complain of the minister having spent too much money, but my complaint is that he has been too careful in his expenditure.
Mr. TAYLOR, That is what we expect of hon. gentlemen on that side.

I am glad I do not disappoint the hon. gentleman. There is in my constituency, and, I think, in adjoining constituencies, very considerable complaint because of failure on the part of the census department to pay accounts for money earned last spring-that is to pay them in full.
And are they not paid yet ?

They have been partially paid, but the complaint is that the minister has been over particular in checking the accounts and refusing payment, I suppose in order to keep within the mark in expenditure. For the purpose of my present argument, I am not concerned whether the expenditure on this census is greater than on the one preceding it or whether the expense is large or small. I am concerned with getting the people paid who did the work. I would ask the minister what are the prospects of these census accounts in the Northwest being paid ?

We are dealing with the accounts as rapidly as we get the proper vuuchers from the individuals who claim the money. We have had a good deal of difficulty in getting vouchers which were acceptable to the accountant and which could pass according to the rules of the department. I think I may say, in a general way, that that is the reason of many of the delays in regard to accounts from the North-west Territories.
I may say also that in the North-west, where distances are great and there is often difficulty in transportation, we have found it hard to get details of the accounts. I think that most of the accounts in the hon. gentleman's (Mr. Oliver's) riding are paid, but that

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: there are still some in other places in dispute between the officials and the department. I can assure the hon. gentleman that we are dealing with these ns rapidly as the staff at my disposal will allow. If the enumerators had been able to file the necessary vouchers for expenses, I have no doubt they would have been paid long ago.

I do not wish to take up the time of the committee in discussing the matter at length, but I would like to bring to the minister's attention the fact that the order requiring vouchers was not issued until after a great part of the work had been done and it had become impossible to get vouchers, and that now the demand for vouchers makes it impossible for the parties to collect their accounts. There should be some other way of arriving at a conclusion than by this demand for vouchers, which it is impossible, at this stage of the game, to obtain.

The hon. gentleman is entirely in error in saying that instructions as to vouchers were not issued until the work was commenced. 1'his was distinctly made known to the chief commissioner for that district, and if he did not give it to the enumerators, that is not the fault of the department, Mr. Deftal, who is the commissioner for the territories, says he gave it to the commissioner for every riding.
At what time ?
On the 17th March, two weeks before the enumeration took place.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: The hon. minister, of course, will not expect this item to go through to-night. I think that before it goes through he should bring the list showing the number of commissioners and enumerators. There is also the question of payments in the constituency of Lisgar. My hon. friend (Mr. Boyd) says that a large number of cheques for census work went out into that constituency at the time of the election. We would like to know to whom they went. The hon. gentleman (Mr. Fisher) might bring down his cheque book with stubs showing the payments made in February.

I should be glad to give the hon. member the information. While I do not expect this item to pass this evening, it is still early, and we can go on threshing it out, and perhaps some other points may arise on which information will be required that I will have to procure and bring down at a subsequent sitting. I would like hon. gentlemen to ask now for what information they want.

I have not been able to be present during the whole discussion. Has the hon. gentleman here a complete list of

the employees in Ottawa in the work of the census ?

Yes. I have here the paylist. It does not include the name of Mr. Blue, the chief commissioner, or Mr. St. Denis or Mr. Cot6, of the Census Department, but it gives the names and salaries of the others connected with the work. I will send the list over to the hon. gentleman.
I shall be glad to see that list. I would also ask the minister out of what fund the investigation which was made in the province of Quebec,, and of which we have heard a great deal, was paid for ?
Out of the census vote.
In what way was it charged-as an investigation ?
No, as part of the work connected with the census.
I was speaking of the investigation which was made in regard to the census of 1891. What was the total amount'!
I do not think I could tell the hon. gentleman off hand what the amount is.
We would like to have the amount, and the way it is charged in the account.
I will get It for the hon. gentleman.
While I am on my feet I would like to know the cost of the census taken in 1891 in the county of Jacques Cartier and the cost of the last census.
I will give the hon. gentleman that.
And who were the commissioners ? Was there only one commissioner, and if so, who was he V
The census of 1891 in Jacques Cartier cost $S42.08 and the census of 1901 cost $2,770.58.
And the name of the commissioner ?
The commissioners were U. H. Dandurand, who received $206.67, and Caron Vallee, who received $201.06.
At whose suggestion were they named ?
I could not say off hand, but I will look it up. I think it was at the suggestion of Mr. Decarie.

I would like to ask the hon. gentleman what authority he had to charge 107
to the cost of the census of 1901 this investigation made as to the census of 1891. I think this is a very important question which I will refer to again when I get the amount. It has always been my impression that the way in which we vote money is extremely vague, and I maintain that a study of the estimates and the voting of the estimates would be much shorter and much less of verbal explanation would be called for, if every item gave distinctly the purpose for which the money was asked. Anybody who takes the trouble to go over the estimates, will, I am sure, come to the conclusion that a "great many questions which are asked on this side of the House would not be asked if the object for which the money is to be voted were clearly designated. But, outside of the general consideration, it seems to me a most preposterous act on the part of the government to take this specific vote given by this House, under the supreme authority which we possess, for the census of one decade, to take a sum which must have been very considerable out of that vote, to make an investigation as to the census of the decade previous. 1 believe there was no authority whatever, and when there has been such a flagrant violation of fact that what has happened in this case has sound principle, I am perfectly convinced that a careful examination of the ends to. Which the money is put, and under the loose system in which we vote it, will reveal the fact that what has happened in this case has happened in a variety of other cases. I will confine my attention to this particular case, and I say it is an absolute violation of the rules and principles which should govern us and which ought to be taken notice of by every fair and impartial member of this House, because we may be on the other side of the House to-thoTrow. It is gross violation of principle that a sum voted for such a specific object as this should be devoted to defraying the expenses of the investigation which was made into the census of 1891. I would ask the hon. minister to explain upon what authority he has violated one of the fundamental rules which should govern us in our financial conduct in this House ?

It is quite a fair question to raise. I felt that the investigation into the accuracy of the census of 1891 was called for, because of the results of the census of 1901 which showed very extraordinary decreases of population in a great many places where the people of the locality were quite satisfied that such decreases could not have occurred. In other cases where the increases were very small indeed the question arose as to how this could be accounted for. It was a question concerning the census of 1901 ana when the suggestion was made, and which came naturally to the minds of many people, that the census of 1891 was unduly swelled and that the apparent anomalies



8395
which existed between the results of the census of 1891 and the results of the census of 1901 were perfectly explainable if we could show that the census of 1891 was unduly swelled, which I think we could show, and which I think we did show, es-pecialy in the province of Quebec, it would be a sufficient explanation of these apparent anomalies and would be a confirmation of the results of the census of 1901. I therefore considered that the results of the census of 1891 were bound up with the question in such a way that the expenditure for this purpose seemed to be perfectly legitimate out of this vote for taking the census of 1901.

I will not deny that the explanation given by the hon. gentleman is a plausible one, but still I maintain that there was no authority given by us to use that money for such a purpose. We will refer to this further when we get the amounts. I would like to ask the hon. minister if he took upon himself, upon his own authority, to make that expenditure and to thus divert money from the use for which it was originally intended. Did he do that of his own volition, or was it done by Order in Council, or how was it done ? How were the accounts passed by the Auditor General ? Having before him the vote which we had given, how could he possibly pass this amount which was intended for taking the census of 1901, and which was not intended to defray the cost of holding an investigation so as to criticise the census .taken ten years before ?	-

'There eertainly was no Order in Council authorizing it to be done. The decision was arrived at after consultation with my colleagues. I did not assume the responsibility entirely on my own shoulders, although I carried out the intention and desire of my colleagues after consultation with them.
Mr. J3RODER. Will the hon. gentleman give the cost of taking the census in the three Bruces in 1891 and 1901 V

I will give the cost in 1891 first and then the cost in 1901 :	East Bruce, $1,330.61 ;
North Bruce, $1,594.51; West Bruce, $1,-359.40. In 1901 the cost was as follows : East Bruce, $2,667.04; North Bruce, $2,911.34; West Bruce, $2,135.36. The population was as follows : In 1891, East Bruce, 21,355; North Bruce, 20,871; West Bruce, 23,377. In 1901 the population was as follows : East Bruce, 19,313; North Bruce, 21,297; West Bruce, 18,410.
It costs many thousands of dollars more in 1901 with a population 6,000 less.

The information obtained at the last cen-.Hon. Mr. .FISHER.
sus was three times as much as in the census of 1891.
What was the cost of the census for King's, N.B., in 1891 and in 1901 ?
What was the amount paid to the commissioner in each year ?
In 1891 the commissioner received $280.20, and in 1901 the commissioner received $316.63.
Have you got the list of the enumerators there ?
Yes, I will hand you the list for the whole province.

I may state that in my county it did seem difficult for the government to get a commissioner. The first man to whom they offered the job said the government owed him more, and he wanted more. He would not take the job, but he recommended another who did take it.	[DOT]

What did they owe him
more for ?
I really cannot tell that. I wish the minister to tell me what was the cost of taking the census in 1891 and in 1901 in the county of Cardwell.
The hon. gentleman confirms my statement that this man would not take the position because he was not paid enough.
No; it was because he said the government owed him more.
I do not know what the government owed him.
Have you found out since ?
No. The census taken in Cardwell in lo91 cost $1,102.94, and in 1901 it cost $1,965.93.
I would ask the minister the same question *with regard to South Grey.
The cost in South Grey in 1891 was $1,047.85, and in 1901 the cost was $2,597.36.
Did the gentleman who refused the commissionership in Cardwell get a better job since ?
I do not know who he was or anything else about him.
Well, it was Mr. Stubbs.
Oh, yes, Mr. Stubbs has a position in my department, but I do not know if it is better or not.
Well, if he did not refuse it, it must be better.
He is in a position whieh is more continuous and possibly is better.

I have now a copy of the circular sent to the enumerators. 1 notice that while first instructions contained the bald statement! that the day shall consist of eight hours, and that they shall not be paid higher than $3 a day. It appears that on the 30th of April an Order in Council was passed forming the schedule upon which they should be paid, but that was long after they were appointed and after the census was taken.
It says they shall be paid at schedule rates.

It says that the day shall be of eight hours of proved effective service, and that the minister shall set forth a table of remuneration which shall not exceed in the aggregate a total of $3 per day for each day of proved effective service for an enumerator; or $4 for a commissioner. That circular was sent out to the census employees. They were furnished with no other schedule, and I claim that they had a right to assume that that was the only binding contract between them and the government, and that they were employed at $3 a day; but after a month, after the work was done, then comes out the other schedule stating that they were only to be paid 5 cents a name. It does seem to me that the government have broken faith with their employees, and have done a great injustice to them; and up to the present several of their enumerators have not been paid, and have refused to take what is offered to them, and I think very properly so.

When the minister the other day was going into the figures of the census of 1891, I think he referred to the towns of Goderich and Clinton, in one of which it was alleged there were on the list the names of some 37 persons who were not really there in 1891. May I ask the minister what means were adopted for making this comparison ?

A gentleman who was thoroughly acquainted with the places, who had lived there for many years before 1891, was employed to ascertain, of his own personal knowledge and from such information as he could get from the old inhabitants of the place, those who were present in 1891, and he was given 1074
a list of the names taken in those municipalities in the census of 1891.
Did the same gentleman act in both towns ?
Yes, Mr. D. F. Macpherson made the investigation in both places.

My recollection is that these two places were the only ones cited by the minister. Can he explain how it was that it was only in the riding of West Huron that he seized on any towns for the purpose of comparison ?
It was not only there. We also made inquiry in East Hastings, North Middlesex, Cornwall and South Norfolk. There were five places in Ontario in which investigations were carried on.
I am speaking from memory, but I think ' Hansard ' will bear me out, that only in those two towns of Goderich and Clinton actual names were picked out. Percentages were given for the other places.
I cannot remember in what places names were picked out.
What was the medium that started the inquiry in these particular ridings ?

They were chosen simply at random. We wanted to get places scattered over the province, and we employed gentlemen who from their residence in the places and their knowledge of the localities were competent to do the work.
Mr. BENNETT This gentleman, Mr. Macpherson, did not explicitly say that the people were not there in that year. It may have" been that they were there part of the year. I think the census of 1891 was taken late in the fall.
No, it was taken in April.

Then, it may have been that the people returned there in the fall. Does Mr. Macpherson allege that they were not there in any part of the year at all ? If he has made any statement in writing, will the minister produce that at the next meeting of the committee ?
The statement was that they were not there on the date the census was taken, that is, on the 6th of April, and had not been there for years before.
Has the minister a written report of Mr. Macpherson ? If so, will it be laid on the Table ?
I have a full copy of the report here, and I will show it to the hon. gentleman.

I was not able to conclude the remarks 1 wished to make to the minister. What I wished to say was that even if the Chief Commissioner did issue the instructions, I am satisfied that these instructions did not in all cases reach the enumerators in time, and for that reason and others of a local character, it was not possible for the enumerators in all cases to follow the instructions as to securing vouchers, and I would urge upon the minister the necessity of relaxing in some degree the requirements in order to clear up the accounts. There will have to be some relaxation.

I would say to the hon. gentleman that in view of just such cases as he mentions, I have given instructions to this effect, that if the enumerators who did not get vouchers would make an affidavit to that effect and supply the details of what they knew they had expended, we would take that and make the payment. But we require something to show us that they were real expenses incurred, and we cannot tsflke a general statement of figures.
Will the minister state in two words what was the nature of the investigation which was made in reference to the census of 1891 ?

The investigation in the province of Quebec was carried on largely in this way. It is a well known fact that every year a parochial census is taken by the Catholic clergy of the province. The figures of that census were taken and compared with the figures of the Dominion census of the same year. The same thing was done for 1891 and 1901, and we found this extraordinary fact, that in 22 counties there was a difference of 44,000 between the parochial census of 1891 and the Dominion census of 1891 an average
difference	of 2,000	per	county	inwhich	the	parochial	census	was	lessthan	the	Dominion	census.	In	these
same 22 counties there was a difference in 1901 of only 8,000. or a difference of about 400 per county. We went further than that, and appealed to the registers of the parishes in which the names were entered. We compared these with the schedules in those counties and the lists of the names which were taken in the Dominion census, and we found name after name in the Dominion census which did not appear in the parochial registers. I made personal inquiries from priests, notaries, and old residents in those particular localities, and I got name after name and names of whole families which the people in those localities declared positively were not there in 1891, and had not been there for five or ten years, and in
some cases twenty years, and in many cases had never been there at all.
Of all this there is an ample report in writing, no doubt ?
Yes, the reports were laid on the Table some time ago.

"Knowing how our clergy take their census, and how their system is necessarily different from that pursued by us, and knowing how their census is limited to those of their own communion, it would not surprise me at all if the results which they arrive at should be different from those we obtain.
Those were taken in purely Catholic counties.

If any argument has been drawn from that, which I believe has been, I should say that the findings of our clergy have been put to very base and irregular uses. I would not at all question the findings of my own clergy, but it would not surprise me that they should be widely different from those of our enumerators, who proceed under a totally different set of rules. There is no ground possible for comparison, but I do not want to speak without examining the record. Would my hon. friend bring to our next meeting, not only the vouchers connected with that investigation. but the books in which the entries were made ? That would greatly shorten the work of my hon. friend and mine. Is this list, which my hon. friend has handed me, really a list of the permanent staff of the census employed at Ottawa ?

That is a list of the people now engaged in the census work here at Ottawa, with the exception perhaps of one or two employees, permanent in the departments, but who are also engaged in this census work. It is a list of the nominees appointed to do the work of tabulation at Ottawa in connection with the census.
Will my hon. friend bring down a complete list of those specially employed at Ottawa on the census of 1901, giving their names and salaries ?
I will provide a supplementary list, if there are any names not on.
Are these officers paid by the day, week or month ?
I think that everybody on the list is paid by the day. They are paid every day right aiong, including Sunday.
Do they work on Sundays ?
No.

When we had a discussion on the census some time ago, the hon. gentleman argued that the Conservative party in 1891 had stuffed the lists in the province of Quebec, and he gave a number of constituencies, in which a large number of families were enumerated in 1891, who were not there at the time. How can he reconcile that with the statement made frequently throughout the country that the French population of the province of Quebec had been under-enumerated in the census of 1891 by the Conservatives, and that Mr. Cote's circular was sent out for the special purpose of guarding against a similar occurrence ?
I am not aware that the charge has ever been made that people were left out in the province of Quebec from the census taken in 1891.

Then why was the Cote circular sent out ? The reason given was that the French families in the province of Quebec had not been properly enumerated in 1891. Yet, according to the hon. gentleman's own statement, instead of people being left out of the census then, the census lists in the province of Quebec were stuffed in 1891.
The reason why the Cote circular, as the hon. gentleman describes it, was sent out, was to obtain a correct census in 1901, without any reference whatever to the census of 1891.
But the hon. gentleman must have heard his colleague's statement that was circulated in the press.
I am not responsible for his statement.

The Minister of Public Works was charged with circulating a statement that the French families of the province of Quebec had not been properly enumerated in 1891, that the Conservative party had not done justice to that population," and that was the reason why this circular was issued.

I sent out that circular for the purpose of getting a correct census in 1901, I never understood that there was any accusation that the French Canadians in the province of Quebec had not then been fully enumerated, but what I did understand-and I think that certain words in the first volume of the census of 1891 will bear me out-was that there were French speaking people all over the Dominion who had not been enumerated as such. There were Acadians in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, and French Canadian people in Ontario and Manitoba. But there was only one description of them, that of French Canadians. A great many of these people, especially
the Acadians, did not return themselves as French Canadians, thinking that ' French Canadian' was a term applied only to the French Canadian habitant of the province of Quebec. There were a large number of people of French origin, and of the Catholic religion, and who are really French nationality, but who were not returned as French Canadians. I think that was the complaint made by certain French Canadian members on the floor of this House after the census of 1891. I was not in the House at the time when the debates took, place, but my recollection is that this is what has been explained to me as having occurred.
Then the Conservative party are not open to the charge of having given credit to Quebec for too large a population in 1891 ?
I am not accusing them of that.
But, on the other hand, the accusation is that they did stuff the lists in the province of Quebec ?
Yes, investigation shows it.

I see the point made by my hon. friend. But, the matter will be thoroughly sifted before this matter is passed. We will know if the statement of the Minister of Agriculture is true and if the charge, the violent charge, made by the Minister of Trade and Commerce is well founded-that there are a very large number of perjurers among the French population of Quebec. That charge so repeatedly made will have to be sifted to the bottom. I can tell hon. members that the people of the province of Quebec, part of whom I represent here, have keenly felt that charge. AVe are Conservatives and Liberals in the province of Quebec and we have our political difficulties as other people have. But I should be very sorry to rise in this House and charge that the Liberal enumerators of 1901 were perjurers. And what is still stranger than the fact of such a charge being made concerning the enumerators of 1891 is the fact that it is proven out of the mouth of our Roman Catholic clergy. We will see the bottom of that before this item passes. For my part, I am prepared to suspend judgment until we have before us all the documents we have a right to see. In the meantime, I will examine the documents so far presented.

Coming to the alleged charges of falsification of the census in Ontario, I am informed that the inquiries were not made at random but specifically in every riding, and that the only county in which "the investigator dared to put down anything definite was the county of Huron. In this case, the statement is made by a Mr. Macplierson. This gentleman does not live in Goderich, but, apparently in Clinton,

as lie writes from Clinton. Who is lie, and what is his occupation ?
1 am informed that Mr. Macpherson is a member of the firm of Macpherson, Glasgow & Co., makers of agricultural implements, and lives in the town of Clinton.

This investigator or inquisitor lives in the village of Clinton, which, I think, is about ten or fifteen miles from Goderich. In 1891 Goderich was returned as having a population of about 4,000. After a lapse of ten years this gentleman goes up there. He does not make a single statement on his own authority, but what he says is ' after making careful inquiries of different old residents.' I suppose he took old people because their memory might he at fault and they might be easily persuaded to agree to what he said. This statement the Minister of Agriculture read out to show that the list for Goderich had been stuffed. The census was taken early in the year 1891. Now, take the first name mentioned as having been improperly included in the census list. This is Elizabeth Tebutt, who was enumerated twice, once in Goderich township and once in Clinton. I know nothing of the case, but I presume this woman was a domestic. She may have been at her home in Goderich township when the enumerator went around, and was proba bly included in the census again by the enumerator for Clinton where she was working. Now, the town of Goderich is a lake port of importance and a number of vesels run in and out of there. I find the name Worthington given here with the remarks that this party was in Chicago in 1891, and another party was in Buffalo, and so on. These men were probably vessel men, and were properly taken by the enumerator at Goderich. Everybody knows that a man connected with a vessel leaves home in the spring for the fitting-out work that is done on the boat. If the bulk of these cases were inquired into, I have no doubt it would be found that these men lived in Goderich and their occupation was such as to take them away during a part of the year. One is represented here as having been in Winnipeg, one in St. Paful, one in Vancouver, and others in other places. What does that indicate ? It indicates that this very inquisitive gentleman-who, I have no doubt we shall find out later on was well paid for his inquisitiveness-learned the names of people who. at some time of the year were away. He does not say that they were away the whole year. They may have been there in 1891 when the census was taken and been away in the fall. On this list are the names of the enumerators whose work is here impugned. Have they been asked for an explanation ?
I do not think so.

Does the hon. minister think it is British fair-play to lay on the Table a statement opposite which is a name of, no doubt, a respectable man of the county of Huron or the town of Goderich, which statement practically brands that man as a perjurer ? I think my former statement is true, that these inquiries were made all over the province from the members representing the ridings, and that the member of that particular riding seemed to be very busy about this town of Goderich and the town of Clinton where he lives. Go all through the list and you find the same thing. Here are two men who were said to have been employed elsewhere in 1891, and the statement does not say they were not there in the spring of the year when the enumeration was taken.
The statements all have reference to the 6th of April.

The minister says that, but Mr. Macpherson does not say it. On the face of it. Mr. Macpherson knew nothing about it. He lives ten miles away from this town. Is the minister going to ask the people of this country to be asses enough to believe that a man who lives twelve miles away from a town can go hack ten years afterwards and pledge his word that on this particular date, the 6th of April, every one of these men were not in that town I live in a town of 3,000 population, and I would hesitate to allege that on the 1st of April of a particular year men were not in that town who perhaps were there. Here is another statement. There is a Mr. Cook, a Mr. Corbett, a Mr. Woodcock, a Mr. Reid and a Mr. Stiver. I do not know any one of those men. Perhaps you do, Mr. Chairman, as you come from Huron ; and would you be prepared to say that these men were perjurers ? Now this man Macpherson would not venture to say this is true under the solemnity of an oath, and lie would not. hold himself responsible that there is one statement true on his own knowledge ; he says that the statements are made to him. I think it is preposterous that the minister should place such a document before the House and make wholesale charges based upon it. I am glad to know that having scoured Ontario front one end to the other in a vain attack on tile census returns of 3891. he was only able to find in this town of Goderich the particular instances of wrongdoing that he mentions, and which, on their very face, will not carry to any fair minded man an idea that there was anything wrong on the part of these enumerators. Now, here is a test for the minister. He has the criminal law of the province of Ontario behind him, and he lias been afraid to prosecute one of these men
for perjury. I ask the minister if lie lias prosecuted one of those men for making false returns ?
No.
Does he propose to prosecute any of those men for fraud ?
I have not proposed to do so.

I admire the hon. gentleman's discretion. Here on the 17th of February this statement is sent in by Mr. Macpherson, and the minister thinks that between man and man it is fair and honest to these gentlemen to make this slander on them without asking them for an explanation.
I want to correct the hon. gentleman in saying that the province of Ontario was carefully scoured to find out those frauds. There was no attempt of the kind in any shape or form.
In no case 7

In no case. There was no inquiry made, and in this very place where an investigation was made there was no preliminary inquiry of any kind. Before the work was commenced we had no idea what the result was going to be. As a matter of fact, there were five places in which this work was conducted, and in two of those places, two townships in one riding, there was evidence that the census was taken correctly in 1891, jind in the others there was evidence that it was not.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Will the hon. gentleman give those statements ?

1 gave them in full to the House not long ago. The places in which the investigation was made were in Huron west, in Goderich and Clinton, in the town of Simcoe, and the village of Port Dover, in the south riding of Norfolk, where also many errors were found. In Cornwall also irregularities were found.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Will the hon. gentleman leave these reports on the Table ?

I will be glad to do so. I may say that the best evidence that there was no preparation for this investigation is the fact that in one place, at all events, no irregularities were found. If our object had been to discover irregularities before we made our investigation, we would not have chosen that plan, but we would have chosen places where we had found irregularities. We just took the places at random, and made the investigation with the results that have been detailed. I have here four of these, and one where there was nothing wrong
found. I will bring the reports down before the next meeting of the House.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I presume these commissioners were paid out of this appropriation the same as in Quebec ?
Yes.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I stated a few minutes ago that the hon. gentleman had a staff composed of one clerk from each constituency in the Dominion, and the hon. gentleman stated a few moments ago that there was a supplementary list to be added. I have added up the numbers, and I find there are 205. names on this pay-list. I find also that he has able bodied men and women working at $1.25 per day, judging from this pay-list. I want the hon. gentleman to tell me how much it cost in 1891 and in 1901 to take the census in the city of Ottawa, where you have to pay for clerical work $1.25 a day ?

I may say that as far as the $1.25 a day is concerned, there are a few clerks who are being paid $1.25 a day. This is because there were a few clerks who were not doing their duty properly and they were cut down from $1.50 to $1.25 a day as a warning and told if they did not do better they would be dismissed altogether.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: There is quite a number of them.
I cannot tell the hon. gentleman how many there are. The expense in the city of Ottawa in 1891 was $1,564.37, and in 1901, $4,573.96.	[DOT]

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
Three times the amount that it cost in 1891. I have just run up this monthly pay-list, and to the end of March,
I find that it takes $10,500 to pay the persons whose names appear here. Then, there is a supplementary list, and there is the commissioner and a large number of the members of the staff who are not on this pay-list at all. There is Mr. Blue, the commissioner, whose name does not appear and that will increase the amount very materially. It is costing $10,500 a month, and from the best information we have it will take two years to complete the work of tabulating the statistics from the 1st of March. To pay this staff it will cost $250,000, to say nothing of the commissioner and the other members of the staff. My hon. friend does not expect to get through in less than two years from March last. The expenditure up to that time is $948,000 to say nothing of the commissioner, or rent, or tlie other members of the staff. This is the ordinary list of pay clerks who are receiving $1.25, $1.60, $1.75, and up to $2 a day. There is one man drawing $100 a month on the list, and he is the only one that I have noticed receiving that amount. I am prepared to say that before the work is

completed $1,250,000 will be nearer the amount expended than the sum stated by the minister.
What is the latest bulletin that has been issued ?
Bulletin No. 7. giving the population by origins and nationalities.

I would like to draw the hon. gentleman's attention to the fact that he has not been very extravagant in furnishing us with copies of the bulletins. I would like to know why the distribution office of the House is not supplied with a reasonable number so that copies can be obtained by members.
I will be glad to send some copies to members of the House.
I think we have advanced a little and that we might now adjourn.
I do not think we have advanced the business very much, but this happens to be as convenient a time as any other to adjourn.

I would like to ask the hon. minister whether he would object to bringing down a detailed statement of a few of the enumerators' accounts ? I would like the hon. gentleman to bring down a statement showing the amounts paid to the enumerators in South Waterloo particularly. Some resolutions reported.

Bill (No. 120) to incorporate the Bishop of Moosonee.-Mr. Taylor.
On motion of the Minister of Finance House adjourned at 1.10 a.m. Thursday.
matter of the most earnest consideration on the part of the government. A good deal of correspondence has taken place on this subject between the Colonial Office and the Canadian government.
Canada wants men, plenty of men ; in the Ncrth-west Territories and towards British Columbia there are thousands of square miles that are lying waiting for settlers. The Boers are the sort of settlers that the Canadian government is looking for. The Dominion government proposes to give a full homestead, consisting of 160 acres of land, to each head of a family that will settle down, as well as to each male over twenty-one, to assist them with money-as settlers are at present assisted-and to admit them to the same terms of civil liberty as any settler.
If so, will ihe government lay the correspondence on the Table of the House ?
There is no such correspondence.
